# Chapter: The Immortal Bridge

Pured Bridge spanned a river so vast it dwarfed most lakes. One of the Belto Kingdom's critical arteries, it had earned its moniker—the Immortal Bridge—through centuries of standing firm against flood, siege, and time itself.

Today, three hundred horses thundered across its ancient stones.

From a distance, the mass of armored bodies appeared as a single writhing organism—only up close could you distinguish individual mounts. The 4th Battalion of the armored elite troops. Speed and shock were their doctrine, compensating for what they lacked in numbers.

"Faster!" Bocard, the battalion commander, urged his men forward. "Secure that watchtower before they sound the alarm!"

If the garrison spotted them, their advantage would evaporate. His soldiers responded with the precision of veterans, deploying advanced riding techniques as they ate up the remaining distance. Three meters from the tower, they launched themselves from their saddles in perfect synchronization—not a single man losing his balance.

*Crack!*

Weighted chains whipped through the air, coiling around the watchtower's support pillars.

"Enem—*urk!*"

The Ares sentries died with the warning half-formed on their lips. By the time they'd registered the threat, it was already too late. The 4th Battalion excelled at precisely this: striking from shadow, swift as death.

"Contact!"

The main guard force didn't realize they were under attack until half their defenses had already fallen. The elite troops were already swarming up the chains, blades flashing in the morning light.

"Light the beacon! Alert the duchy!"

Pured Bridge occupied open ground—easily monitored, easily secured. That very visibility had bred complacency. The defenders had never imagined an assault *here*, of all places, and they'd grown lax because of it.

The defense captain lunged for the signal fire. The armored troops cut him down before he'd taken three steps, stamping out the flame before it could catch.

The ground commander—Baphrang—spotted Bocard among the attackers and his face twisted with betrayal. "You're using Duke Ares' own techniques! Without him, you'd be *nothing!* How dare you spill blood on the land of the man who trained you?"

Bocard's expression didn't waver. "We trained under Duke Ares for the *royal family*. He was a great general. A great teacher. And now he's a traitor who turned his back on his rightful liege."

**[Quest Failed!]**

**[You have failed to convince Captain Bocard of the 4th Battalion.]**

**[New Objective: Retreat from Pured Bridge! Warn Duke Ares of the enemy's advance!]**

*Shit.*

Baphrang had been bitter about this posting. Guarding a bridge no one would ever attack? It felt like being shoved aside, denied any chance at glory while others racked up achievements in real battles. 

Now he understood. This wasn't the periphery.

This was the *lynchpin.*

Pured Bridge was the shortest route to Ares' stronghold. If it fell, the duke would face a full assault with no time to prepare proper defenses.

*I have to warn him.*

Guild chat would be simple. A quick message, instant communication. But the moment the elite troops had appeared, the quest parameters had triggered—all remote communication was blocked. If he wanted to warn anyone, he'd have to run there himself.

"Hah!"

Baphrang vaulted over the tower's edge. Six meters straight down in full plate armor—the fall damage alone would cripple most players. But Baphrang had reached his third advancement. He had control.

Just before impact, he activated Charge, twisting mid-air to redirect his momentum laterally rather than downward, defying gravity through pure skill.

He didn't account for Bocard.

The spear captain had already predicted his landing zone.

*Thunk!*

"*Ghhk!*"

The spear punched through Baphrang's cuirass and into his chest—a perfect strike to the heart. His health dropped by a third in an instant. Critical hit. Mortal wound.

And then—

*Crackle-BOOM!*

Lightning erupted from the spear's shaft, arcing through Baphrang's body. The additional damage wasn't even the worst part—the electric shock paralyzed him, locking every muscle.

*Bastards!*

He couldn't move. Couldn't even reach for a potion. Could only watch helplessly as the elite troops closed in for the kill.

*This is it.*

Death meant failure. Failure probably meant expulsion from the Ares Army. His future—everything he'd worked toward—about to disappear because he'd been too complacent, too focused on his wounded pride to do his damn job.

The hoofbeats grew louder.

Baphrang closed his eyes.

Then—

*KRAKOOOM!*

Lightning split the sky.

Not Bocard's parlor trick. Real lightning—a column of raw fury that made the spear's shock look like static electricity.

*BOOM!*

The sound was physical, hammering into their chests.

The armored elite troops scattered on pure instinct, abandoning their killing blow in favor of survival. For several heartbeats, no one moved. No one breathed.

Then the impossible happened.

The lightning... *stayed.*

Still crackling on the ground where it had struck. Still pulsing with lethal energy.

And then it *moved.*

*Crackle-snap!*

The lightning bolt surged forward like a living thing.

Confusion rippled through the battalion. Lightning didn't behave like this. Lightning struck and dispersed. It didn't linger. It didn't *hunt.*

They didn't understand what they were seeing.

Asura. The warrior class that one man in hundreds of thousands had elevated beyond its normal limits through sheer mastery.

"Regas!" Baphrang's shout was half relief, half disbelief.

"*Lightning Dragon Ascension!*"

Regas became the storm.

His movement speed and agility multiplied beyond human limits as he tore through the armored formation. He didn't run—he *manifested*, appearing and disappearing faster than the eye could track.

*Crack!*

One soldier down.

*Boom!*

*Crash!*

Two more.

*BOOM-BOOM-BOOM!*

An onslaught of fists and feet, each strike accompanied by thunder, each impact delivering a jolt of electricity that locked muscles and shattered balance. The elite troops—these soldiers who'd trained for years under Ares himself—couldn't even respond. Couldn't raise their weapons. Couldn't do anything but fall.

*I can't—*

*—can't even see him!*

Then Pon arrived.

"Didn't want to interfere, honestly."

He'd known Baphrang would be an enemy soon enough. The smart play was to let him die. But Regas had grown up practicing Taekwondo—the sport had instilled certain values. You didn't abandon allies in trouble, even if those allies were temporary.

"But what Regas wants, Regas gets." Pon grinned. "Lucky for you."

He hurled his spear with everything he had.

*SHRIEEEEK—*

Belial's Spear—his reward from the National Competition—screamed through the air. It punched through the first stunned soldier. And the second. And the third. The Mach Spear technique manifested sonic booms and flames in its wake, the spear itself moving faster than sound.

Baphrang's jaw went slack.

He'd known the Overgeared members were strong. Top-tier players. But he'd mentally categorized most of them below Grid, Yura, Jishuka, and Katz—the true monsters of the guild.

He'd been wrong.

*Regas' speed... Pon's destructive power... This isn't top-class.*

*This is world-class.*

Goosebumps rose on his arms despite the situation.

Regas approached, offering his hand with that genuine, transparent smile of his. "Can you stand?"

Baphrang stared at him.

*You know I'll be your enemy someday. You know this is temporary. And you're still treating me like a real comrade?*

This wasn't coincidence. Regas hadn't just happened to be nearby. He'd *come* to help.

*How big is the Overgeared Guild's heart?*

Meanwhile, what had Baphrang been doing? Sulking about his post. Neglecting his duty because he wasn't getting personal glory. Thinking about his own achievements instead of his team.

"I'm... ashamed."

He clasped Regas' hand and pulled himself up, looking at the martial artist with newfound respect and admiration.

"If Grid has subordinates like you... I can't even imagine what kind of person he must be."

Regas blinked, clearly confused.

Pon laughed so hard he nearly dropped his spear.

***

**Guild Chat Update:**

**@ The 4th Battalion has collapsed. Pon and Regas confirmed the kills.**

The Ares command staff stared at their screens.

The 4th Battalion was small but elite—their guerrilla tactics were a nightmare to counter. And it wasn't Grid or Jishuka who'd destroyed them, but Pon and Regas?

"Baphrang must have set up perfect defenses at the bridge," someone suggested. "Funneled them into a kill zone."

Nods all around. But Scott and Luck exchanged glances.

"No," Scott said slowly. "The Overgeared Guild is stronger than we estimated."

"The loot from the great demon raid," Luck added. "Whatever they got must have been significant. They're operating at a completely different level than during the Belial fight."

"If they're that much stronger than the Belial raid..." Someone swallowed hard. "What does that make Jishuka?"

"Grid's probably on par with Ares leading twenty thousand troops," Scott said grimly. "Maybe thirty thousand."

Silence.

"Which means Grid will be confident enough to send Jishuka against the 1st Battalion alone."

"She'll die. The 1st Battalion has mixed unit composition—their defense is too layered. The red phoenix flames won't penetrate armored troops."

"But she'll soften them up. Drain their stamina, force them to burn through resources. Then we mop up the exhausted survivors and claim the experience."

The Ares members were nodding, already calculating their share of the spoils, when a new message appeared.

**@ 1st Battalion has made contact with an Overgeared member. But...**

**@ What?**

**@ It's someone called Euphemina. Not Jishuka.**

**@ Euphemina?**

**@ Who the hell is that?**

Scott and Luck stared at each other.

*Why does nothing ever go according to plan?*
